contextId.information: The word "house" is a metonym for the people who lived in the house. AT: "his family" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: his house

contextId.information: "He" refers to Elkanah, but the UDB and many other versions regard this as metonymy for Elkanah and his family. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: he worshiped Yahweh

contextId.information: Here "feet" is a metonym for the way a person walks, which in turn is a metaphor for the way a person decides how to live his life. AT: "keep his faithful people from making foolish decisions" or "enable his faithful people to make wise decisions" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: guard the feet of his faithful people

contextId.information: The words "wear an ephod" are a metonym for the work of the priests who wear the ephod. AT: "to do what I had commanded the priests to do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: to wear an ephod before me

contextId.information: The word "house" is a metonym for the people who lived in the house. Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:1sa:02:27|2:27]]. AT: "the family of your ancestor"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the house of your ancestor

contextId.information: The name of the town is a metonym for the people living in the town. "both the people of Ashdod and the people in the land surrounding Ashdod" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: both Ashdod and its territories

contextId.information: The hand is a metonym for God punishing the people. "Yahweh was punishing the people there very severely" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the hand of God was very heavy there

contextId.information: The word "city" is a metonym for the people of the city. Possible meanings are 1) the words "went up to the heavens" is an idiom for "was very great." AT: "the people of the city cried out very loudly" or 2) the words "the heavens" is a metonym for the people's gods. AT: "the people of the city cried out to their gods." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the cry of the city went up to the heavens

contextId.information: Here "hand" is a metonym used to represent God's power to afflict or discipline. AT: "why he has not relieved your suffering" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: why his hand has not been lifted off of you

contextId.information: Here "hand" is a metonym used to represent God's power to afflict or discipline. AT: "stop punishing you, your gods and your land" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: lift his hand from you, from your gods, and from your land

contextId.information: The word "house" is a metonym for the people who live in the house and their descendants. AT: "all of the descendants of Israel" or "all of the Israelite people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the entire house of Israel

contextId.information: The word "hand" is a metonym for power. AT: "Yahweh used his power against the Philistines" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: The hand of Yahweh was against the Philistines

contextId.information: Here "the voice" is a metonym for the will or the desire of the people. AT: "Do what the people say" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Obey the voice of the people

contextId.information: Here the metonym "the ears of Yahweh" refers to Yahweh. Samuel prayed to Yahweh repeating all that the people said. AT: "he repeated them to Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: he repeated them in the ears of Yahweh

contextId.information: Here the word "hand" is a metonym for control. AT: "from the control of the Philistines" or "so the Philistines will no longer control them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: from the hand of the Philistines

contextId.information: The name "Israel" is a metonym for the people of Israel. "I brought the people of Israel out of Egypt" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: I brought up Israel out of Egypt

contextId.information: The word "hand" is a metonym for power. AT: "the power of the Egyptians ... the power of all the kingdoms" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the hand of the Egyptians ... the hand of all the kingdoms

contextId.information: Here "name" refers to the reputation of Yahweh. AT: "So that people will continue to honor and respect Yahweh " (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: For the sake of his great name

contextId.information: Here "heart" represents Yahweh's desire or will. The phrase "man after his own heart" is an idiom that means to be a person who does what Yahweh desires. AT: "a man who is the kind of person he wants" or "a man who will obey him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: a man after his own heart

contextId.information: Here "heart" refers to Jonathan's desires. AT: "everything that you desire to do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: everything that is in your heart

contextId.information: Here "hand" refers to the power to defeat them. AT: "will enable us to defeat them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: has given them into our hand

contextId.information: Here "hand" refers to power to defeat the Philistines. AT: "will enable Israel to defeat them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: has given them into the hand of Israel

contextId.information: The people were not afraid of the oath, but of the punishment that was associated with breaking the oath. AT: "the people were afraid of what Saul would do to them if they broke his oath" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the people feared the oath

contextId.information: This is a metonymy that represents the nation of Israel. AT: "for Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: for the land

contextId.information: Here "approaching God" is associated with asking him counsel. AT: "Let us ask God what we should do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Let us approach God here

contextId.information: This is a metonymy that represents the people of Israel. AT: "the Israelites" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Israel

contextId.information: This refers to the people of Edom. AT: "the Edomites" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Edom

contextId.information: The word "hand" represents control. AT: "out of the control" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: out of the hands

contextId.information: This refers to the message that Yahweh spoke. AT: "the message of Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the words of Yahweh

contextId.information: Here "sight" refers to his opinion based on what he saw. AT: "in your own opinion" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: in your own sight

contextId.information: Here "voice" refers to the commands that Yahweh spoke. AT: "the things that Yahweh commanded" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the voice of Yahweh

contextId.information: Here "sight" refers to Yahweh's thoughts or opinion. AT: "what Yahweh considers to be evil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: what was evil in the sight of Yahweh

contextId.information: Here "word" refers to the command that Yahweh spoke. AT: "refused to do what Yahweh commanded" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: rejected the word of Yahweh

contextId.information: Here "voice" refers to what the soldiers asked Saul to do. AT: "did what they asked" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: obeyed their voice

contextId.information: Here "word" refers to the command that Yahweh spoke. AT: "refused to do what Yahweh commanded" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: rejected the word of Yahweh

contextId.information: Here "see" means to evaluate something. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh does not see as man sees

contextId.information: The word "house" refers to the household or family. AT: "will no longer require his family to pay taxes" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: will make his father's house free from taxation in Israel

contextId.information: The heart failing represents being terrified and losing confidence. AT: "Do not let anyone be terrified"  or "Do not let anyone lose their confidence" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Let no man's heart fail

contextId.information: Bears and lions use their paws when they attack, so the word "paw" represents the attack. AT: "from the attack of the lion and from the attack of the bear" or "from the lion and the bear" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: from the paw of the lion and from the paw of the bear

contextId.information: Here "name" represents God's power or authority. AT: "with the power of Yahweh" or "with the authority of Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: in the name of Yahweh

contextId.information: Swords and spears are examples of battle weapons. They represent human ways of fighting. AT: "The victory that Yahweh gives does not depend on sword and spear" or "when Yahweh gives us victory, he does not depend on how we fight" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh does not give victory with sword or spear

contextId.information: Giving the Philistines into Israel's hand represents helping Israel to defeat the Philistines in battle. AT: "he will help us defeat you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: he will give you into our hand

contextId.information: Here "Israel and Judah" represent the people of all of the tribes. AT: "all the people in Israel and Judah loved David" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: all Israel and Judah loved David

contextId.information: Here "head" refers to a position of authority. AT: "acting as their leader" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: standing as head over them

contextId.information: The word "house" is a metonym for the people who live in the house. AT: "David's family"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: house of David

contextId.information: Here "on hand" is a metonymy that means available. AT: "What food do you have that you can give me?" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: what do you have on hand?

contextId.information: Here "on hand" is a metonymy meaning "available." AT: "Do you have a spear or sword that you can give me?" Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:1sa:21:03|21:3]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Now is there not here on hand any spear or sword?

contextId.information: Here "took ... to heart" is a metonymy to think seriously about what was said. AT: "David thought seriously about what the servants said" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: David took these words to heart

contextId.information: The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. This can be translated in active form. AT: "whom your family honors" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: is honored in your house

contextId.information: Here "house" represents "family." AT: "to all my father's family" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: to all the house of my father

contextId.information: The word "house" is a metonym for the family that lives in the house. AT: "your father's family" or "your father's descendants" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: your father's house

contextId.information: The word "hand" is a metonym for the work done with the hand. AT: "did not do anything to kill" or "refused to kill" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: would not put out their hand to kill

contextId.information: Here "attacked" means killed. AT: "he killed many people in the city of Nob" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: he attacked Nob

contextId.information: Here "hand" represents power or control. AT: "give me and my men over to Saul" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: surrender me and my men into the hand of Saul

contextId.information: The word "hand" is a metonymy for power. AT: "did not allow Saul to have power over David" or "did not allow Saul to do as he desired with David" or "did not allow Saul to capture David" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: did not give him into his hand

contextId.information: Here "hand" is a metonym for Saul and his power. AT: "For Saul my father will not find you" or "For Saul my father will never be able to have power over you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: For the hand of Saul my father will not find you

contextId.information: The hand is a metonym for the ability to cause harm. AT: "to harm him in any way" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: to put out my hand against him

contextId.information: The hand is a metonym for the ability to cause harm. See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:1sa:24:05|24:6]]. AT: "I will not harm you in any way"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: my hand shall not be against you

contextId.information: The word "hand" is a metonym for power. AT: "so that you have no power over me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: from your hand

contextId.information: It is important for each family in Israel to have descendants from generation to generation carrying on the family name and land inheritance. AT: "you will not destroy my family and descendants" or "you will allow my family to live" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: you will not destroy my name out of my father's house

contextId.information: Here "house" represents family. AT: "He was a descendant of the family of Caleb" or "He was a descendant of Caleb" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: He was a descendant of the house of Caleb

contextId.information: If swords are not known in your language, you can treat "strap on his sword" as a metonymy meaning to prepare for war. AT: "'Every man, prepare for war.' And every man prepared for war. David also prepared for war" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: "Every man strap on his sword." So every man strapped on his sword. David also strapped on his sword

contextId.information: The hand is a metonym for what a person does with the hand. Abigail assumes that David should allow Yahweh to take vengeance for him. AT: "taking vengeance yourself instead of letting Yahweh do it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
contextId.quote: avenging yourself with your own hand

contextId.information: The word "hand" here is a metonym for the action taken by the hand. AT: "by my own actions" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: with my own hand

contextId.information: The word "voice" is a metonym for the message the person speaks and a synecdoche for the person who speaks. AT: "have listened to what you have told me" or "will do as you have advised me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: have listened to your voice

contextId.information: Abigail responded by bowing. The reader should understand that she was probably already standing when the men were talking to her in [[:en:bible:notes:1sa:25:39|25:40]], and so the word "arose" is a metonym for deciding to bow down. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: She arose, bowed herself

contextId.information: Abishai speaks as if the enemy were a small object that God had put into David's hand. The word "hand" is a metonym for the power the hand can wield. AT: "God has given you complete control over your enemy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: God has put your enemy into your hand

contextId.information: The hand is a metonym for the harm a hand can do. AT: "do anything to harm" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: extend my hand against

contextId.information: This speaks of evil as if it were an object that is held in the hand. Here "hand" represents a person acting or doing something. Possible meanings are 1) David really does want Saul to answer the question. AT: "What have I done wrong?" or 2) this rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. AT: "I have done nothing wrong!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: What evil is in my hand?

contextId.information: The word "hand" is a metonym for the person's power. "Yahweh gave me an opportunity to attack you today" or "Yahweh placed me where I could easily have killed you" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Yahweh put you into my hand today

contextId.information: Here "his heart" is a metonymy that means to himself. AT: "David thought to himself" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: David said in his heart

contextId.information: The word "life" is a metonym for the person. AT: "me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: my life

contextId.information: Here "hands" refers to control. AT: "you will not ... violate the trust I have in you by allowing my master to control me again" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: you will not ... betray me up into the hands of my master

contextId.information: "the Philistines fought against the people of Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the Philistines fought against Israel
